Executive Summary

The Chevron Pipeline and Power (CPP) Salinas River Cogeneration Facility (SRCF) is located in San Ardo, California and produces steam and electricity from natural gas. The steam is used for enhanced oil recovery. Electrical power generated is consumed by Chevron with surplus power sold to the local utility.
SRCF located in San Ardo, California in the County of Monterey. SRCF operates one natural gas
fired combustion turbine generator. SRCF is a cogeneration plant that produces electricity and
steam which is utilized for enhanced oil recovery. SRCF utilizes Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) technology to reduce combustion Oxides of Nitrogen (NOx) emissions. SCR is a post-combustion flue gas NOx emission control technology that removes NOx from the flue gas downstream from the combustion process. A reducing agent is used to reduce NOx emissions by oxidation-reduction reactions in the presence of a catalyst. Injection of the reducing agent/air mixture into the combustion exhaust stream before the catalyst initiates the reactions and achieves the desired removal of NOx emissions upstream from the stack.
The SRCF uses anhydrous ammonia (Chemical Abstracts Service #7664-41-7) as the reagent for the SCR system. The maximum amount stored on site is 1700 gallons this is limited to state regulatory requirements that limit the amount of volume in the vessel to 85% capacity. The site consists of two 1,000-gallon storage vessels for the anhydrous ammonia; however, only a single 1,000-gallon (850-gallon limit or 4,276 lbs) anhydrous ammonia tank is provided to support the SCR at the SRCF. Maintenance and loading of the anhydrous ammonia storage tank have been contracted out. Transport of anhydrous ammonia to SRCF is accomplished using tanker trucks, with individual deliveries of no more than 1700 gallons. Deliveries are scheduled every three to five weeks. The storage tank lies within an enclosed dike and is equipped with a deluge system. The deluge system is

currently not in use. In addition, the ammonia-handling facility is equipped with process area detectors to protect workers and equipment in the event of a malfunction.
The use of equipment for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia in support of the SRCF
SCR system will require compliance with EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP). The quantity of ammonia on-site does not exceed EPA RMP reportable quantity thresholds for Program 3; however, is required to conform with Program 2 requirements and additional exceeds CalARP threshold quantities of (500lbs). SRCF is required to implement a EPA RMP Program Level 2 plan pursuant to Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 40, Section 68. SRCF is also required to implement a CalARP plan pursuant to California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.
The CalARP plan is administered by the local administering agency (AA). In Monterey County, the AA is the local Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) - the Monterey County Health Department (MCDH). Additional information specific to CalARP is submitted to the MCDH. Copies are available on-site inside the Control Room Building at SRCF and easily accessible to employees and emergency personnel.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/RESPONSE POLICY

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility (SRCF) accidental release prevention policy involves a
unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance
practices, and tested management system practices. Applicable procedures of the State of California and United States Environmental Protection Agency (US-EPA) are adhered to, including training, systems management, and emergency response procedures. SRCF recognizes its responsibility to make employee, community and environmental protection an integral part of daily operations. It is committed to be a responsible member within the community by giving top priority to conducting

operations in a safe and environmentally sound manner.
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the plant. CPP policy is adherence to all federal, state and local laws. Chevrons Policy 530 Operational Excellence is the governing overarching policy for protecting the safety and health of people (workforce and public) and the environment, and to conduct operations reliability and efficiently In addition, the Operational Excellence Management System (OEMS) is how Chevron systematically manages
workforce and pubic safety and health, process safety, reliability and integrity, environment, efficiency, security and stakeholder engagement issues.
It is the policy of SRCF that every employee is entitled to a safe and healthful place in which to work. SRCF incorporates the concepts of environmental responsibility and with safety into all aspects of base operations and public. As part of SRCF's obligation to protect the integrity of humans, environmental, physical, and financial resources, and to conserve and efficiently utilize those resources, SRCF will: comply fully with laws regulating environmental protection and workforce and public health and safety; furnish work places free of recognized hazards likely to cause injury to people and the environment; train employees in safe and environmentally conscious practices and require compliance with environmental, health, and safety regulations, policies, and procedures; and provide professional staff to maintain and support environmental, health, and safety programs.

SAFETY INFORMATION

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility keeps a variety of technical documents utilized to maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.
Chemical specific Information, including exp

osure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This Information is supplemented by documents specifically addressing known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, the plant has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition). The covered process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).
The plant also maintains numerous technical documents providing information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure safety features in the process are not compromised.
A management of change process is in place and is used to document and manage changes within the plant affecting safety and environment, as well as changes which modify the facility or change operating conditions.
Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) and Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCAs) assessments are conducted to identify, characterize, and safely manage actual or potential hazards associated with operations. The accidental release prevention strategy is based on the seven elements of the CalARP Program 2 Prevention Program as follows.

HAZARD REVIEW

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility has a comprehensive program to help ensure hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and verify adequate controls

are in place to mitigate the hazards.
The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility primarily uses the HAZOP (Hazard and Operability) methodology to identify and mitigate process hazards and risks. The HAZOP methodology is recognized as a systematic and thorough hazard evaluation technique. The analyses are conducted using a team of people with operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures as necessary.
The HAZOP findings are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to HAZOP findings is based on risk ranking assigned by the HAZOP team. This ranking ensures the findings associated with the highest risk are prioritized over findings with a lower risk ranking. All approved mitigation options in response to HAZOP team findings are assigned to responsible personnel and tracked to completion.
To verify the process control functions still adhere to the design intent, the HAZOP is revalidated every five years.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility maintains written operating procedures addressing various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) emergency shutdown (4) normal shutdown, and (5) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and certified as current and accurate. The procedures are kept current and accurate by reviewing and revising as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. Operating procedures contain upper and lower operating limits and consequence of deviation information. Operating procedures are readily available.

TRAINING

New o

perators are evaluated to assess the level of initial training required and appropriate initial training is provided. After successfully completing the initial training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process specific duties and tasks. Once a new operator demonstrates the ability to safely perform assigned duties and tasks, the operator may work independently. All operators periodically read and revalidate the operating procedures to verify the operating procedures are accurate. Formal operating procedure refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All operations, maintenance, and construction personnel receive training on plant health/safety hazards and plant emergency procedures before beginning work in the plant. All training is documented including the means (oral or written tests/quizzes, skills demonstration, etc.) used to verify training is understood.
MAINTENANCE
The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility has well-established practices and procedures in place to properly maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, control systems, electrical systems, rotating equipment, and emergency shutdown systems. This comprehensive maintenance program includes: (1) conducting training; (2) developing written procedures based on manufacturer's recommendations, operations, and maintenance history; recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices; (3) performing inspections, tests, and preventative maintenance; (4) correcting identified deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures to ensure proper equipment, components, materials, and spare parts are used when repairs are made. A computerized maintenance management system is in place to ensure inspections and preventative maintenance activities are performed as required.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility conducts compliance audits to verify elements of this accidental release prevention program are adequate and

functioning as designed.
Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. Corrective actions are assigned in response to the audit findings and are tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent compliance audit reports are retained.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The Salinas River Cogeneration Facility promptly investigate high severity incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in consequences such as, fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury requiring care beyond first aid. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent or reduce the likelihood of a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to local management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with identified employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years and the information is reviewed during the next HAZOP revalidation.

FIVE VEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Salinas River Cogeneration Facility has had no accidents with offsite consequences within the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

An Emergency Action Plan includes specific actions to be taken by employees in response to the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The emergency responder is the Monterey County Fire Department and MCDH. The plan includes procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases, informati

on on emergency health care, date of the most recent review or update of the emergency response plan, and date of the most recent emergency response training for employees. The name and telephone number of the local agency with which emergency response activities and the emergency response plan is coordinated is provided, along with a list of other federal or state emergency plan requirements to which SRCF is subject.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The SEKR Cogeneration Plant will continue to focus on incident free operations (IFO) and the CPP Managing Safe Work (MSW) process which includes safe work practices designed and intended to manage high risk/ high consequence work activities. In support of these efforts, the plant will continue to provide training, utilize Job Safety Analysis (JSA), incorporate process safety principles and practices to prevent loss of containment events, and encourage the use of Stop Work Authority when unsafe conditions or actions may be present in the workplace.
The hazards of the process were identified with plant personnel and during a HAZOP Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) conducted on 4/4/2016 and scheduled for revalidation on or before the 5th year validation date. SRCF has adopted a reduced storage amount of ammonia as an additional safety measure. That ammonia system project PHA node was revalidated utilizing the HAZOP methodology on 4/28/2020.

Salinas River Cogen Program level changes occurred in 12/08/2020 from program 3 to the new establish program level 2.   Anhydrous Ammonia TQs were reduced for the facility and communications were sent to the local Certified Unified Program Agencies (CUPA) and approved. Since that date, the facility has been managed under program 2 elements/ requirements.
